awd_titl_txt: Laser spectroscopy of metal and semimetal molecules
awd_abstract_narration:
In this project funded by the Chemical Structure, Dynamics, and Mechanisms A (CDSM-A) program of the Chemistry Division, Professor Michael D. Morse of the University of Utah is using sophisticated laser techniques to provide highly precise measurements of the strength of the chemical bonds between transition metals such as titanium, iron, cobalt, and nickel and main group elements such as carbon, oxygen, silicon, and sulfur.  Transition metals such as these are widely used to transform petroleum into useful chemicals and to synthesize new pharmaceuticals.  They are also used by nature in the active sites of enzymes that are essential for life.  A more detailed and precise understanding of the chemical bonding in such systems is important for their accurate modeling, which is, in turn, essential for a full understanding of these catalytic processes.  In addition, Professor Morse is using the same laser techniques to investigate the chemical bonding and electronic structure of boron clusters.  Just as carbon clusters have become technologically important with the discovery of the fullerenes and carbon nanotubes, boron clusters show unusual chemical properties that may become important in future applications.  This research investigates unusual electronic properties in far greater detail than has been accomplished previously. The most important broader impact of the proposed work is the inspiration and training of a new generation of physical chemists. The research is technically and conceptually challenging. Students working on these projects are continually forced to troubleshoot their instruments and to develop strong problem-solving skills, which are transferable to many different arenas of scientific endeavor.  In an outreach effort to the local community, Dr. Morse continues to give twice-yearly workshops for high school Advanced Placement (AP) chemistry teachers who are challenged by physical chemistry concepts. These workshops enhance the teachers? interest in and knowledge of physical chemistry, so that they can inspire a new generation of high school students.  

The research uses resonant two-photon ionization spectroscopy to probe the absorption spectrum of molecules such as TiC, FeO, CoC, etc., and uses the observation of a sharp predissociation threshold in a dense vibronic spectrum to measure the bond dissociation energies of these molecules to high precision.  The predissociation threshold is easily identified because when it is reached, the molecules fall apart faster than they can be ionized, leading to a loss of signal in the mass spectrum.  Analogous measurements of the bond dissociation energies of cations, such as TiC+, TiSi+, etc. are undertaken using a cryo-cooled ion photodissociation spectrometer, in which the cation is mass-selected, cooled to low temperatures, irradiated, and the resulting fragment ion is detected.  When there is a large density of vibronic states in the vicinity of the lowest separated fragment limit, a sharp fragmentation onset identifies the bond energy to high precision.  The studies of boron clusters use previous work in which photoelectron spectra were obtained of mass selected boron cluster anions as a guide to locate electronic transitions in the neutral species.  These are then recorded at a resolution that is about 50 times better than that obtained in the photoelectron experiments, allowing the vibrational structure to be analyzed.  This work, particularly the work on transition metal bond energies, has broader impacts by providing accurate benchmarks for the development of improved quantum chemical methods that may then be used to successfully treat systems that are too large for such high precision experimental work.  A broader impact of the work comes in the broad applicability of the precisely measured bond dissociation energies. This is fundamental work that extends our chemical knowledge and chemical intuition. It also contributes to the development of computationally accurate methods by providing a highly accurate database by which these methods may be tested.

por.por_cntn:
NSF Grant CHE-1664962 has funded research on small transition metal molecules in which a transition metal is bonded to a p-block element, with the goal of obtaining fundamental information concerning the chemical bonding, electronic structure, and bond dissociation energies of these species.  All of the studies undertaken under the auspices of this grant have been directed toward the precise and accurate measurement of bond dissociation energies (BDEs).

When an open d-shell transition metal atom approaches a p-block element, there are a large number of different electronic states that can be formed by the various ways the d- and p-electrons can be arranged, how their spins are coupled, and whether they go into bonding or antibonding orbitals.  Although generally one of these electronic states emerges as the ground state, as one moves higher and higher in energy, one encounters more and more electronic states.  When a molecule with a high density of electronic states is excited to an energy slightly about the energy of the ground state separated atoms, the high density of states guarantees that the molecule can find a pathway to dissociation on a sub-nanosecond to few-nanosecond time scale.  This is the basis for our method of measuring BDEs.

Our spectroscopic method first excites the molecules with one photon, then ionizes the excited molecules when a second photon is absorbed.  The resulting ions are detected in a time-of-flight mass spectrometer.  When the density of electronic states that can be reached is high, the resulting spectrum is nearly continuous and is far too complicated to be interpreted.  However, when the excitation photon energy exceeds the BDE, the molecule falls apart more quickly than it can be ionized, leading to an abrupt drop in molecular ion signal to baseline.  It is this drop to baseline that provides the bond energy of the molecule.

During the three-year time frame of this grant, we have been able to measure the BDEs of 61 different transition metal-main group molecules, which have been reported in 11 publications.  These include 8 transition metal borides (MB), 11 carbides (MC), 5 oxides (MO), 12 silicides (MSi), 14 sulfides (MS), 9 selenides (MSe), one chloride (WCl), and one transition metal methylidyne (Y-CH).  Many of these bond dissociation energies had never been measured before; for those that had been previously measured, our highly precise methods reduced the error limits by factors of 5 to 100 and led to significant changes in accepted values for several species.  By conducting these measurements across the entire transition metal series and on a variety of p-block ligands, we have been able to elucidate the periodic trends in chemical bonding.  As one example, we have found that electron deficient p-block elements (such as 2p1 boron, 2p2 carbon, or 3p2 silicon) make far stronger bonds to transition metals with an excess of d-electrons.  Thus, the most strongly bound MB molecule we have found is RhB, with a BDE of 5.252(3) eV.  Similarly, the most strongly bound MSi molecule is PtSi, with a BDE of 5.325(9) eV.  When the p-block element is electron rich (such as 3p4 S or 4p4 Se), the strongest bonds are formed with the electron-deficient transition metals.  For these species, the most strongly bound molecules are HfS, with a BDE of 5.780(20) eV, and HfSe, with a BDE of 5.154(4) eV.  These trends are readily understood using simple concepts from molecular orbital theory. 

One of the most important uses for our measurements is their use as benchmarks for chemical computations.  Generally speaking, the accurate calculation of bond dissociation energies is one of the most important but also most difficult tasks of quantum chemistry.  Our highly precise values allow computational chemists to know when a particular methodology can be successful, and when it gives suspect or erroneous results.  A number of computational chemists are already using our values to test computational methods.

In another finding, chemists have always known that there is a great chemical similarity between sulfur and selenium, which are congeners in the periodic table.  With our highly precise bond dissociation energies, we were able to show that the BDEs of the metal sulfides track those of the selenides amazingly closely.  The metal sulfides are more strongly bound by 15.4%.  This comparison would have been impossible without our investigation, as most of the metal selenide BDEs were experimentally unknown.
